author: ralexstokes
content: generally, the bigger the sync committee size, the better as for the foreseeable future, light clients will only have security guarantees up to an honest majority of this committee

author: ralexstokes
content: and it is harder to corrupt if the committee is bigger (requires more stake and more manipulation of the committee shuffling)

author: ralexstokes
content: at the same time, light clients will need to download N pubkeys for a committee of size N (so they can in fact verify committee signatures over the chain they want to follow)

author: ralexstokes
content: so it can't be too big

author: ralexstokes
content: we generally have the working rule that committees of size 128 are safe enough from epoch to epoch (there is a more rigorous derivation of this number in the phase 0 specs)

author: ralexstokes
content: and now the question is how much bigger should the sync committees be, given that they last for longer than an epoch (and so are that much more susceptible to adaptive adversarys) ?

author: ralexstokes
content: and i don't know if there was a super rigorous process here but the current spec says 512

author: ralexstokes
content: as for the actual period, the idea was basically "how frequently should a light client have to sync new committee data" and the approximate answer is "i can open some light client app once a day to pull new data from the network"

author: ralexstokes
content: the period currently in the spec is more like 2 days and the thinking was to amortize the overhead from the size of the committee (which is doubled from say 256, which even may be enough)

author: ralexstokes
content: but the preference is to have larger committees where possible -- esp important for high-value light clients, like bridges etc
